docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The decision of Local 1199, the National Health and Human Service Employees Union, to organize its own health maintenance organization (news article, Dec. 17) is a commendable step in the union's long battle to force New York's various insurers and health care providers to become accountable for their actions.

headline.main: Union-Run H.M.O. Will Aid the Working Class

docs.lead_paragraph: The National Institutes of Health said today that researchers could begin a disputed study to determine the best way for illicit drug users to get clean needles in hopes of avoiding AIDS and other diseases. Dr. Harold E. Varmus, the director of the institutes, said in a memorandum that he had accepted the conclusions of an expert advisory panel, which said last week that the proposed trial in Alaska was ethical and could produce useful information.

headline.main: Disputed Study on Clean Needles for Drug Addicts Gets Approval

docs.lead_paragraph: In the first formal response to calls for a reduction in the index that measures inflation, the head of the agency that compiles the statistic said today that no significant remedies could be adopted before 1999. ''There is not a lot, in the short term at least, for us to be doing,'' Katharine G. Abraham, the Commissioner of Labor Statistics, said at a briefing about the conclusion of a Congressionally appointed panel that the Consumer Price Index exaggerates inflation by 1.1 percentage points annually.

headline.main: Labor Statistics Chief Takes Issue With Critics of Inflation Index

docs.abstract: Labor Statistics Comr Katharine G Abraham, in first formal response to calls for reduction in Consumer Price Index, says that no significant remedies can be adopted before 1999 (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Dow Up 39.98 Points As I.B.M. Rises Stocks rose as the Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged. I.B.M. climbed sharply, recouping some of its losses from a selloff in computer-related shares that began last week and giving impetus to the Dow industrials, which finished up 39.98 points, at 6,308.33. Though the broader market did not do as well as the blue chips -- declining issues led advancers on the New York Stock Exchange -- the Nasdaq composite managed to rise 5.34 points, closing at 1,266.32. $(Page D8.$) The Frontier Corporation, stung by the loss of a big wholesale customer, warned analysts that its long-distance telephone revenue would be well below analysts' expectations. Its shares tumbled 21 percent in heavy trading. $(D5.$) The prices of Treasury securities fell following a November housing report that was stronger than expected. The 30-year bond yield rose to 6.65 percent from 6.62 percent. $(D18.$) Conrail Shareholder Vote Ordered A judge ordered Conrail to let shareholders vote on a crucial aspect of its $8.5 billion deal to merge with CSX. A group of investors questioned the merger's fairness. $(D2.$) Deadline Near in Prudential Case The last opportunity for policyholders of Prudential Insurance to battle the company on their own over whether they were cheated by agents is this week. A lawyer said that by last week, about 9,000 policyholders had declared that they were opting out of a class-action settlement, not nearly enough for the company to withdraw from the settlement. $(D4.$) LVMH Proceeding With DFS Deal LVMH Moet-Hennessy Louis Vuitton, one of the world's leading purveyors of high-priced perfume, liquor and other luxury goods, won the go-ahead for its $2.47 billion deal for a controlling interest in the DFS Group, a chain of duty-free shops that sells its wares. $(D2.$) American Home Products in Deal American Home Products said that it was exercising an option to buy 40 percent of Genetics Institute that it does not already own for about $1 billion. Last week an F.D.A. panel recommended approval of Genetics' blood clotting treatment for hemophilia B. $(D4.$) Goldman, Sachs Profits Surge Goldman, Sachs said that its pretax earnings rose 69 percent in the fiscal fourth quarter, to $743 million. Thanks to a boom in underwritings and mergers, Wall Street is on track for record profits this year. $(D2.$) With the lean times apparently over for now, employees on Wall Street are not just busy making deals. They are partying, too. The champagne is flowing at rates not seen since the 80's, and the current wave of consumption is no less lavish. But it is intricately choreographed to seem less conspicuous. $(B1.$) F.T.C. Clears Ciba-Sandoz Merger The F.T.C. removed the last hurdle to the merger of Ciba-Geigy and Sandoz, after winning an agreement intended to insure competition in the development of gene therapy treatments. The companies also agreed to sell two businesses. $(D7.$) 2d Flu Shot Urged for Some Because 5.8 million of the 75 million doses of flu vaccine produced this season were not full strength, Federal health officials advised doctors to consider giving another shot to some people. The vaccine with some weakened doses was Fluogen, made by Warner Lambert's Parke-Davis division. $(A18.$) Going Public in a New Tokyo Market ATL Systems, a five-year-old Japanese software company that lost $230,000 on sales of $120,000 last year, went public in Tokyo, where its shares closed up 51 percent. It is the first company to use a new over-the-counter market for developing technology companies that want to go public. Market Place. $(D8.$) The 240Z, New for '97 Nissan has been buying up 240Z sports cars from the early 1970's, intending to sell them after they have been restored. Though the cars will lack amenities like air bags and cup holders, one thing about them will be updated for the 90's -- the price. Advertising. $(D6.$)

docs.lead_paragraph: Reacting to a barrage of criticism from state officials and consumer groups, the White House said today that an Administration proposal to scale back inspections of many nursing homes would be thoroughly revised to guarantee the protection of patients. ''It's probably not going anywhere any time fast,'' President Clinton's press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said of the original proposal, which was recently sent to state nursing home inspectors around the country.

headline.main: U.S. Puts Off Plan to Pare Nursing Home Inspections

docs.abstract: Clinton Administration, reacting to barrage of criticism from state officials and consumer groups, says proposal to scale back inspections of nursing homes will be thoroughly revised to guarantee protection of patients (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Even though the A.F.L.-C.I.O. failed in its efforts to return Congress to Democratic control this year, John J. Sweeney, the federation's president, outlined ambitious legislative goals yesterday that included revising the new welfare law and revamping health care to provide medical insurance to more children. Asserting that the 13-million-member federation plans to speak out more for working families, he said the A.F.L.-C.I.O. would push to soften the welfare law's provisions that deny benefits to immigrants and that are expected to push more children into poverty by denying their parents benefits.

headline.main: Organized Labor Outlines Ambitious Goals for the Next Congress

docs.abstract: AFL-CIO president, John J Sweeney, outlines federation's ambitious goals, even though union failed in efforts to return Congress to Democratic control; will seek revision of new welfare law and revamping of health care to provide medical insurance to more children (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Conseco Inc., a rapidly growing insurer, said yesterday that it was buying Pioneer Financial Services Inc. in a stock swap valued at $417 million. Conseco also agreed to take on $60 million of Pioneer's debt. The transaction with Pioneer, an insurance holding company specializing in health and life insurance for retired people, was the seventh such deal by Conseco this year.

headline.main: Conseco in Deal to Buy Yet Another Insurer

docs.abstract: Conseco Inc says it will buy Pioneer Financial Services Inc in stock swap valued at $417 million; transaction is seventh deal by Conseco this year; profile of Pioneer, which is based in Schaumberg, Ill (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: One of New York State's most powerful unions is planning to market its own new managed-care health plan to the state's 2.5 million union members, a move that could deal a serious blow to huge insurers like Empire Blue Cross and H.I.P., which have relied predominantly on labor unions for their patient base. The union health plan is being created by 1199, the National Health and Human Service Employees Union, which represents 120,000 health care workers in the state. A limited version of the plan covering only outpatient care is already being offered to 1199 members, and the full plan, including hospital benefits, will be marketed to other unions beginning next year.

headline.main: Union Plans To Market Own H.M.O.

docs.abstract: National Health and Human Service Employees Union, one of New York State's most powerful unions, is planning to market its own new managed-care health plan to state's 2.5 million union members, move that could deal serious blow to huge insurers like Empire Blue Cross and HIP, which have relied predominantly on labor unions for their patient base (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the wake of a law passed last year that guarantees new mothers insurance coverage for a 48-hour stay after childbirth, the Legislature is scheduled to consider a bill today that would make insurers pay for three days of hospitalization after a mastectomy. Women need the time to deal with the loss of a breast and doctors need the time to monitor the patient for infections, said one of the bill's sponsors, Assemblyman Joseph Azzolina, a Republican of Middletown. Many policies now cover only one day of hospital care after the operation. The bill would have the same limits as the childbirth law, which covers only insurance policies written in the state.

headline.main: A Bill to Cover Hospital Stays

docs.abstract: New Jersey Legislature to consider bill that would make insurers pay for three days of hospitalization after mastectomy (New Jersey Daily Briefing) (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''Hospitals Looking Abroad to Keep Their Beds Filled'' (front page, Dec. 10) suggests an opportunity for Americans, particularly those who are uninsured or have high deductibles, to obtain good, more affordable medical treatment abroad.

headline.main: See the World and Have a Bargain Surgery
